Introduction

Primary lung cancer (bronchogenic carcinoma) is the leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide.  Most cases are related to cigarette smoking.  Lung cancer is classified into different histologic subtypes (small cell vs nonâ€“small cell) that have implications in terms of presentation and management.

Pathogenesis and pathophysiology

Risk factors

Risk factors for primary lung cancer include:

  • Cigarette smoking:  Firsthand smoking is linked to 85% of cases (~30-fold risk increase compared to never-smokers).  Cigarette smoke contains hundreds of carcinogens (aldehydes, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, nitrosamines) that cause DNA damage through covalent adducts or oxidative radical formation.
  • Radon exposure:  Radon (222Rn) gas is the second most common cause of lung cancer in the United States.  It is a radioactive element found within the Earth (
    figure 1
    ), including residential soil and groundwater.  Radon gas emits alpha particles (the most mutagenic type of ionizing radiation), creating genomic damage when inhaled.
  • Other established risk factors:  Secondhand cigarette smoke, occupational exposures (eg, asbestos in pipe workers, silica dust in miners and quarry workers), and previous chest radiation therapy (eg, breast cancer) are all risk factors.

Years of genotoxic stress (eg, from cigarette smoke, other carcinogens) overwhelm the intrinsic DNA repair mechanisms, leading to inactivating mutations of tumor suppressor genes (eg, TP53, RB1) or activating mutations in oncogenes (eg, KRAS, BRAF) that normally prevent or promote division respectively.

Driver mutations

Certain driver (gain-of-function) mutations, repeatedly observed in lung cancer, can drive neoplasia (eg, in never-smokers).  They include chromosomal rearrangements resulting in constitutively active receptor tyrosine kinases (eg, EML4-ALK (

figure 2
), CD45-ROS1 fusion proteins).  Activating mutations in EGFR and HER2 are strongly associated with lung adenocarcinoma in never-smoking Southeast Asian female patients.

These driver ("actionable") mutations can be specifically targeted with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (eg, erlotinib for EGFR-positive lung cancer, crizotinib for ALK-rearranged lung cancer), which display selective action and less off-target toxicity (ie, precision medicine).  Therefore, dedicated molecular testing (eg, next-generation sequencing) for driver mutations is the standard of care for treatment planning.

Carcinogenesis

Lung cancer generally emerges from the metaplasia-carcinoma sequence (gradual buildup of mutagenic damage).  For example, squamous metaplasia (

figure 3
) is a precancerous lesion that progresses to squamous cell carcinoma.

Histologic subtypes

Primary lung cancer is generally classified (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
) into small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) and nonâ€“small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).

Small cell lung carcinoma (15% of cases)

SCLC arises from pulmonary neuroendocrine (Kulchitsky) cells.  The primary tumor usually originates in the central airways (mainstem or segmental bronchi) and tends to grow rapidly due to its undifferentiated nature.  Histologically, SCLC (

image 1
) appears as sheets of primitive blue cells with a high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio, staining positive for neuroendocrine markers (eg, chromogranin A, synaptophysin, CD56).  Central necrosis is common due to the high rate of growth.

Nonâ€“small cell lung carcinoma (85% of cases)

NSCLC encompasses 3 main histologic subtypes:

  • Adenocarcinoma (~40%) arises from secretory cell types (type II pneumocytes [secrete surfactant] and Club cells [secrete glycosaminoglycans and mucins]).  It is the most common form of lung cancer among both smokers and never-smokers.  The tumor usually originates peripherally (ie, distal bronchi or alveolar ducts).  Histologically, lung adenocarcinoma (
    image 2
    ) appears as proliferations of mucin-producing cells that adopt glandular or papillary structures.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma (~30%) arises from the columnar respiratory epithelium.  Therefore, the tumor usually originates in the central airways.  Histologically, lung squamous cell carcinoma (
    image 3
    ) appears as infiltrating nests of polygonal cells, often with intercellular bridges (epithelial desmosomes) and keratinization.
  • Large cell carcinoma (~10%) is a poorly differentiated cancer with an uncertain cellular origin (possibly very dedifferentiated epithelial cells).  The tumor usually originates in the periphery.  Histologically, pulmonary large cell carcinoma (
    image 4
    ) exhibits a highly aggressive growth pattern (ie, central necrosis, numerous mitotic figures) with no specific differentiation (ie, no glandular structures as with adenocarcinoma, no keratin as with squamous cell).

Pulmonary carcinoid tumor

Pulmonary carcinoid tumor (PCT) is another rare (<5%) form of primary lung cancer.  PCT is the most common form of lung cancer in adolescents and young adult never-smokers.  Like SCLC, PCT is derived from bronchial neuroendocrine cells.  Unlike SCLC, PCT is a well-differentiated neoplasm with a slow, noninvasive growth pattern.  It usually originates within the major airways and almost always has an endobronchial component.  Histologically, PCT (

image 5
) appears as nests of uniform cells, with "salt-and-pepper" chromatin, embedded in a delicate hypervascular network.  Like gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors, PCTs can secrete serotonin and histamine but at insufficient levels needed to produce overt carcinoid syndrome.

Clinical presentation

Asymptomatic lung cancer

The incidence of lung cancer in smokers is approximately 1% per year (~40% over a lifetime).  Approximately 25% of new lung cancer cases are asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis.  The only externally visible sign of otherwise asymptomatic lung cancer is digital clubbing (

image 6
).  Asymptomatic lung cancers (ie, small focal tumors) are usually caught at an early stage.  Given the high incidence of asymptomatic lung cancer in smokers and the potential for curative resection, screening using an annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is offered based on certain characteristics (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Screening has a mortality benefit (number needed to screen = 220 to prevent 1 death).

Local effects of primary tumor

In contrast to asymptomatic lung cancer, symptomatic lung cancer tends to be diagnosed at an advanced stage and is rarely curable.  The tumor can produce symptoms through direct invasion or compression of airways, vasculature, nerve structures, or pleura and chest wall.

Airways

  • Tumors can cause extraluminal compression or endoluminal obstruction of the trachea and bronchi, resulting in progressive dyspnea, resorptive atelectasis, and/or postobstructive pneumonia.
  • Centrally located tumors (eg, SCLC, squamous cell carcinoma) are more likely to cause airway obstruction than peripheral tumors (eg, adenocarcinoma).

Vasculature

  • Tumors can erode into the pulmonary vessels, causing hemoptysis that ranges from minor (eg, episodes of blood-streaked sputum) to massive (eg, >600 mL/24 hr).  Erosion into the bronchial arteries (high pressure) is more dangerous than erosion into the pulmonary arteries (low pressure).
  • Upper lobe and mediastinal tumors can compress the superior vena cava (SVC), leading to venous congestion (
    figure 4
    ) of the face, neck, and upper extremities.  Symptoms include facial plethora and orthopnea and are aggravated by bilateral arm elevation (Pemberton sign).

Nerve structures

Tumors in the superior sulcus (

figure 5
) (ie, Pancoast) can compress or invade critical neural structures passing through the thoracic inlet, producing a variety of manifestations (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).

  • Cervical sympathetic chain:  Horner syndrome (ipsilateral miosis, ptosis, and hypohidrosis).
  • Brachial plexus:  Hand or forearm weakness and muscle atrophy.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve:  Hoarseness due to vocal cord paralysis.
  • Phrenic nerve:  Hemidiaphragm paralysis (dyspnea, orthopnea, elevated hemidiaphragm).

Posterior tumors can also invade the neural foramina and enter the dural space to cause thoracic cord compression, manifesting a sensory and motor level with weakness (eg, paraplegia) and spasticity.

Pleura and chest wall

The cancer-related pain from chest wall invasion (eg, ribs) is described as "gnawing," interferes with or awakens patients from sleep, and typically requires aggressive treatment (eg, opioids).

Paraneoplastic syndromes

Lung cancer can be accompanied by an array of paraneoplastic syndromes (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
) caused by the ectopic production of hormones from the tumor tissue.

SCLC is most closely associated with neuroendocrine paraneoplastic syndromes such as:

  • Syndrome of inappropriate diuretic hormone (SIADH):  Euvolemic hyponatremia, which can be severe (eg, confusion, seizures).
  • Ectopic ACTH secretion (Cushing syndrome):  Hypertension, insulin resistance, lipodystrophy (moon facies, "buffalo hump") and atrophic striae, and hypokalemia (mineralocorticoid cross-reactivity of cortisol).
  • Lambert-Eaton myasthenia syndrome (autoantibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels) and cerebellar degeneration (autoantibodies to Purkinje cells).

Squamous cell NSCLC is most closely associated with ectopic parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) secretion:  hypercalcemia (eg, depression and cognitive impairment, constipation, nephrolithiasis, polyuria).

Adenocarcinoma NSCLC is most closely associated with venous thromboembolism (Trousseau syndrome) due to the prothrombotic nature of mucin and hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (ie, digital clubbing plus joint pain due to periostitis).

Distant metastases

Lung cancer disseminates through lymphatic and hematogenous spread.  Clinical manifestations are related to the metastatic site involved (eg, seizure or focal neurologic deficits with brain metastases, recurrent effusion with pleural metastases, bone pain).

Differential diagnosis

Solitary pulmonary nodule (â‰¤3 cm)

The most common radiographic abnormality (found incidentally on unrelated chest imaging or discovered during low-dose chest CT screening) requiring follow-up is a solitary pulmonary nodule (SPN), defined as an opacity â‰¤3 cm in diameter.  SPNs could represent a variety of malignant or benign entities (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).  The likelihood of malignancy is increased by concerning features (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
), namely:

  • Patient:  Age >60, current or previous smoking, and family history of lung cancer.
  • Size:  SPNs â‰¥0.8 cm (require further investigation with positron emission tomography or biopsy).
  • Borders:  SPNs with spiculated or scalloped borders (indicate invasive growth).
  • Location:  SPNs in the upper lobes (reflect the greater concentration of inhaled carcinogens).

SPNs without concerning features are generally followed with serial imaging at regular intervals.  The volume doubling time (VDT) is a useful predictor of malignancy.  Malignant SPNs tend to have an intermediate VDT, whereas benign SPNs tend to have a very fast (eg, <20 days for infection) or a slow (>500 days for lipoma or congenital lesions) VDT.

Pulmonary mass (>3 cm)

In current or former smokers, pulmonary masses >3 cm are most likely to represent lung cancer regardless of other characteristics.  Several benign conditions such as chronic infections (eg, fungal pneumonia), vasculitic or inflammatory lung disease (eg, granulomatosis with polyangiitis), and congenital lesions (eg, arteriovenous malformations) are in the differential diagnosis.

Diagnostic strategies

Diagnosis always requires tissue sampling.

  • A sample of the primary tumor can be obtained (via CT-guided percutaneous biopsy or transbronchial biopsy), alongside imaging using a dedicated scan (eg, whole body PET-CT) to identify lymph nodes or distant sites that are metabolically active (eg, have an avid update of the radiotracer fluorodeoxyglucose [FDG]), presumed to reflect malignant spread.
  • Often, when there is concern that the cancer has already spread (eg, to pleural fluid or lymph nodes), a sample is obtained from the site that would assign the most advanced stage, as this determines management (discussed later).  For example, positive cytology (ie, malignant cells) on pleural fluid analysis (via thoracentesis) establishes stage IV; positive lymph node involvement (via endobronchial ultrasound and transbronchial needle aspiration [UBUS-TBNA]) establishes stages II to III.
  • Finally, in patients with a high-risk SPN or mass who have no lymphadenopathy or other lesions suggestive of metastases and are good surgical candidates, a lobectomy (or segmentectomy) to remove affected lung regions is performed and allows for simultaneous diagnosis and cure.

A core biopsy is usually preferred over fine needle aspiration or cytology because it preserves tissue architecture, allowing for more detailed histologic characterization, and provides a higher cell yield, enabling molecular testing (eg, driver mutations).

Staging, management and prognosis

Lung cancer treatment is determined by histologic subtype (SCLC vs NSCLC) and stage.

SCLC

SCLC has extremely high rates of DNA synthesis and is very responsive to chemotherapy (eg, topoisomerase inhibitors) and radiation.  Limited SCLC (ie, confined to one lung) is curable, whereas extensive SCLC has a poor prognosis.

NSCLC

NSCLC staging is based on the TNM classification system (Tumor size and extent, Nodal involvement, and presence of distant Metastases), with combinations of T, N, and M determining cancer stage (I through IV).  Stages I and II are generally early-stage (vs advanced-stage).

  • Early-stage tumors (eg, confined to ipsilateral lung and lymph nodes) can be cured through surgical resection (ie, lobectomy).  Adjuvant radiation therapy and chemotherapy are sometimes given to eliminate residual cancer cells.  The cure rate is high (>80%).
  • Advanced-stage tumors (eg, spread beyond ipsilateral lymph nodes) are generally treated with chemotherapy plus radiation (chemoradiation).  Surgical resection is anatomically impossible due to the size and complexity of the primary mass.  The response rate is variable, with a 5-year survival of approximately 20%.
  • Metastatic lung cancer (ie, spread to contralateral lung, pleura/pericardium, or remote organs) is incurable and is treated with palliative chemotherapy to reduce tumor burden and improve quality of life.  Malignant pleural effusions typically recur and can be managed with indwelling pleural drainage systems.  The prognosis is poor, with 5-year survival <5%.

In addition, some tumors express antigens that allow them to disable the adaptive immune system.  Most notably, the programmed death ligand-1 (PD-L1) is an immune checkpoint antigen that arrests proliferation lymphocytes (ie, T-cell exhaustion).  Checkpoint immunotherapy (

figure 6
) with PD-L1 inhibitors (eg, nivolumab, pembrolizumab) reactivates these T cells and can produce dramatic results in NSCLC (possibility for complete remission).

Oncologic emergencies

Lung cancer is generally treated on an outpatient basis.  However, some situations warrant hospitalization and aggressive treatment.  These oncologic emergencies include metabolic and mechanical emergencies.

Metabolic emergencies

  • Tumor lysis syndrome:  Usually seen during treatment-induced necrosis of rapidly growing tumors (eg, SCLC) but can sometimes occur spontaneously.  Treatment involves aggressive intravenous fluid therapy and rasburicase.
  • Severe hypercalcemia:  Usually associated with squamous cell NSCLC.  Treatment involves aggressive intravenous fluid therapy, possible hemodialysis for renal failure, and bisphosphonates for concurrent bone lesions.
  • Severe hyponatremia:  Usually associated with SCLC-induced SIADH.  Treatment involves hypertonic saline (if acute encephalopathy or seizures) followed by gradual correction over several days (eg, free water restriction, demeclocycline).

Mechanical emergencies

  • SVC syndrome (due to tumor compression):  SVC syndrome can progress to life-threatening upper airway or cerebral edema.  Urgent stenting is required to restore venous drainage from the head and neck.
  • Epidural spinal cord compression:  Emergency imaging (spinal MRI) and intervention (eg, surgery and/or radiation, high-dose corticosteroids) are required to decompress the cord and preserve neurologic function.
  • Pericardial tamponade:  Pericardial tamponade is treated with pericardiotomy (fenestration) if the patient's hemodynamic status is stable and emergency pericardiocentesis if hemodynamic collapse is imminent (ie, hypotension).

Summary

Primary lung cancer, the leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide, develops due to the continuous buildup of mutagenic damage, primarily caused by cigarette smoke and radon exposure.  Symptomatic lung cancer is due to local effects, paraneoplastic syndromes (eg, syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion), or distant metastases.  It is rarely curable, emphasizing the importance of screening to detect early-stage disease.  Diagnosis requires biopsy for histologic classification (small cell lung cancer versus nonâ€“small cell lung cancer [adenocarcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma]) and additional testing for targetable driver mutations (eg, EGFR mutation) and immune checkpoint biomarkers (eg, programmed death ligand-1) expression in nonâ€“small cell lung cancer.  Treatment is determined by disease staging:  Early-stage tumors can be cured through surgical resection, advanced-stage tumors are treated with chemotherapy and radiation, and metastatic lung cancer is treated with palliative chemotherapy.
